DNDQuickReferenceAutoCloseDialogsHint: Automatically closes the previous dialog box when opening a new reference
DNDQuickReferenceButtonTabHint: Choose the tab where the D&D Rules button will be displayed.
DNDQuickReferenceCategoriesmovementDescr: You can move at any time during your turn (before, after, or during actions).
DNDRulesMovementMoveBullet1: If you have more than one speed, such as your walking speed and a flying speed, you can switch back and forth between your speeds during your move. Whenever you switch, subtract the distance you've already moved from the new speed.
DNDRulesMovementMoveBullet2: You can move through the space of an ally, a creature that has the Incapacitated condition, a Tiny creature or a creature that is two sizes larger or smaller than you.
DNDRulesMovementMoveBullet3: Another creature's space is difficult terrain for you unless that creature is Tiny or your ally.
DNDRulesMovementMoveBullet4: You can't willingly end your move in a space occupied by another creature. If you somehow end a turn in a space with another creature, you have the Prone condition, unless you are Tiny or are of a larger size than the other creature.
DNDRulesMovementClimbDescription: Movement cost: each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot
DNDRulesMovementClimbBullet1: Each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot of movement while climbing. If you have a climb speed, you ignore this extra cost.
DNDRulesMovementClimbBullet2: May involve a Strength (Athletics) check if the climb is difficult.
DNDRulesMovementSwimDescription: Movement cost: each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot
DNDRulesMovementSwimBullet1: Each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot of movement while swimming. If you have a swim speed, you ignore this extra cost.
DNDRulesMovementSwimBullet2: May involve a Strength (Athletics) check if you're swimming in rough waters.
DNDRulesMovementDropProneBullet1: You can drop prone without using any of your speed.
DNDRulesMovementDropProneBullet2: To move while prone, you must crawl or use magic such as teleportation
DNDRulesMovementCrawlDescription: Movement cost: each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot
DNDRulesMovementCrawlBullet1: Each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot of movement while crawling.
DNDRulesMovementStandUpDescription: Movement cost: half of your speed, rounded down.
DNDRulesMovementStandUpBullet1: You can't stand up if you don't have enough movement left or if your speed is 0
DNDRulesMovementHighJumpBullet1: You leap into the air a number of feet equal to 3 + your Strength modifier if you move at least 10 feet on foot immediately before the jump.
DNDRulesMovementHighJumpBullet2: When you make a standing high jump, you can jump only half that distance.
DNDRulesMovementHighJumpBullet3: You can extend your arms half your height above yourself during the jump. Thus, you can reach a distance equal to the height of the jump plus 1.5 times your height.
DNDRulesMovementHighJumpBullet4: In some circumstances, your DM might allow you to make a Strength (Athletics) check to jump higher than you normally can.
DNDRulesMovementLongJumpBullet1: You cover a number of feet up to your Strength score if you move at least 10 feet on foot immediately before the jump.
DNDRulesMovementLongJumpBullet2: When you make a standing long jump, you can leap only half that distance
DNDRulesMovementLongJumpBullet3: If you land in difficult terrain, you must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or have the Prone condition.
DNDRulesMovementLongJumpBullet4: May involve a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check to clear a low obstacle (no taller than a quarter of the jump's distance). You hit the obstacle on a failed check.
DNDRulesMovementImproviseSubtitle: Any stunt not on this list
DNDRulesMovementImproviseDescription: Perform any movement or stunt you can imagine
DNDRulesMovementImproviseBullet1: When you describe a kind of movement not detailed elsewhere in the rules, the DM tells you whether it is possible and what kind of roll you need to make, if any, to determine success or failure.
DNDRulesMovementDifficultTerrainDescript: Moving in difficult terrain costs an additional 5ft per 5ft of movement
DNDRulesMovementDifficultTerrainBullet1: Every foot of movement costs 1 extra foot.
DNDRulesMovementDifficultTerrainBullet2: Difficult terrain isn't cumulative; either a space is difficult terrain or it isn't.
DNDRulesMovementGrappleMoveDescription: Drag or carry the grappled creature with you
DNDRulesMovementGrappleMoveBullet1: If you move while grappling another creature, every foot of movement costs 1 extra foot unless the grappled creature is Tiny or you are two or more sizes larger than it.
DNDRulesMovementTravelPaceDescription: Travel Pace for Fast, Normal and Slow Travel outside of combat.
DNDRulesMovementTravelPaceBullet1: Establish a marching order while you travel.
DNDRulesMovementTravelPaceBullet2:
PaceMinuteHourDay
Fast400 feet4 miles30 miles
Normal300 feet3 miles24 miles
Slow200 feet2 miles18 miles
DNDRulesMovementTravelPaceBullet3: Fast Travel imposes Disadvantage on a traveler's Wisdom (Perception or Survival) and Dexterity (Stealth) checks.
DNDRulesMovementTravelPaceBullet4: Normal Travel imposes Disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.
DNDRulesMovementTravelPaceBullet5: Slow Travel grants Advantage on Wisdom (Perception or Survival) checks.
DNDRulesMovementTravelPaceBullet6: Travelers in wagons, carriages or other land vehicles choose a pace as normal. Characters in a waterborne vessel are limited to the speed of the vessel and don't choose a pace.
DNDQuickReferenceCategoriesactionDescrip: You can also interact with one object or feature of the environment for free.
DNDRulesActionAttackDescription: Perform a melee or ranged attack with your weapon
DNDRulesActionAttackBullet1: When you take the Attack action, you can make one attack roll with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike.
DNDRulesActionAttackBullet2:
Equipping and Unequipping Weapons.
You can either equip or unequip one weapon when you make an attack as part of this action. You do so either before or after the attack.
If you equip a weapon before an attack, you don't need to use it for that attack. Equipping a weapon includes drawing it from a sheath or picking it up. Unequipping a weapon includes sheathing, stowing, or dropping it.
DNDRulesActionAttackBullet3:
Moving Between Attacks.
If you move on your turn and have a feature, such as Extra Attack, that gives you more than one attack as part of the Attack action, you can use some or all of that movement to move between those attacks.
DNDRulesActionUnarmedStrikeDescription: A punch, kick, head-butt, or similar forceful blow
DNDRulesActionUnarmedStrikeBullet1: Whenever you use your Unarmed Strike, choose one of the following options for its effect.
DNDRulesActionUnarmedStrikeBullet2:
Damage.
You make an attack roll against the target.
Your bonus to the roll equals your Strength Mod + Prof Bonus.
On a hit, the target takes Bludgeoning damage equal to 1 + Strength Mod.
DNDRulesActionGrappleDescription: Attempt to grab a creature or wrestle with it
DNDRulesActionGrappleBullet1: Whenever you use your Unarmed Strike, choose one of the following options for its effect.
DNDRulesActionGrappleBullet2:
Grapple.
The target must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (it chooses which), or it has the Grappled condition. The DC for the saving throw and any escape attempts equals 8 + Strength Mod + Prof Bonus.
DNDRulesActionGrappleBullet3: This grapple is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you and if you have a hand free to grab it.
DNDRulesActionShoveDescription: Shove a creature, either to knock it prone or push it away from you
DNDRulesActionShoveBullet1: Whenever you use your Unarmed Strike, choose one of the following options for its effect.
DNDRulesActionShoveBullet2:
Shove.
The target must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (it chooses which), or you either push it 5ft away or cause it to have the Prone condition. The DC for the saving throw and any escape attempts equals 8 + Strength Mod + Prof Bonus.
DNDRulesActionShoveBullet3: This shove is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you.
DNDRulesActionShoveBullet5:
Optional. Shove Aside.
The target must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (it chooses which), or you push it 5ft to a different space within its reach. The DC for the saving throw and any escape attempts equals 8 + Strength Mod + Prof Bonus.
The target has advantage on this save.
DNDRulesActionShoveBullet6: This shove is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you.
DNDRulesActionMagicDescription: Cast a spell that has a casting time of an action or use a feature or magic item that requires a Magic action to be activated.
DNDRulesActionMagicBullet1:
One Spell With A Spell Slot Per Turn.
On a turn, you can expend only one spell slot to cast a spell. This rule means you can't, for example, cast a spell with a spell slot using the Magic action and another one using a Bonus Action on the same turn.
DNDRulesActionMagicBullet2:
A Clear Path To The Target.
To target something with a spell, a caster must have a clear path to it, so it can't be behind Total Cover.
DNDRulesActionMagicBullet3:
Longer Casting Times.
If you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 minute or longer, you must take the Magic action on each turn of that casting, and you must maintain Concentration while you do so. If your Concentration is broken, the spell fails, but you don't expend a spell slot.
DNDRulesActionDashDescription: Gain extra movement for the current turn
DNDRulesActionDashBullet1: The increase equals your Speed after applying any modifiers.
DNDRulesActionDashBullet2: If you have a special speed, such as a Fly Speed or Swim Speed, you can use that speed instead of your Speed when you take this action. You choose which speed to use each time you take it.
DNDRulesActionDisengageDescription: Your movement doesn't provoke Opportunity Attacks for the rest of the turn
DNDRulesActionDisengageBullet1: Your movement doesn't provoke Opportunity Attacks for the rest of the turn
DNDRulesActionDodgeBullet1: Until the start of your next turn, any attack roll made against you has Disadvantage if you can see the attacker, and you make Dexterity saving throws with Advantage.
DNDRulesActionDodgeBullet2: You lose this benefit if you have the Incapacitated condition or if your Speed is 0.
DNDRulesActionHelpDescription: Grant an ally advantage on an Ability Check or Attack Roll
DNDRulesActionHelpBullet1: When you take the Help action, you do one of the following:
DNDRulesActionHelpBullet2:
Assist an Ability Check.
Choose one of your skill or tool proficiencies and one ally who is near enough for you to assist verbally or physically when they make an ability check. That ally has Advantage on the next ability check they make with the chosen skill or tool. This benefit expires if the ally doesn't use it before the start of your next turn.
The DM has final say on whether your assistance is possible.
DNDRulesActionHelpBullet3:
Assist an Attack Roll.
You momentarily distract an enemy within 5ft of you, giving Advantage to the next attack roll by one of your allies against that enemy. This benefit expires at the start of your next turn.
DNDRulesActionHideBullet1: With the Hide action, you try to conceal yourself. To do so, you must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity (Stealth) check while you're Heavily Obscured or behind Three-Quarters Cover or Total Cover, and you must be out of any enemy's line of sight; if you can see a creature, you can discern whether it can see you.
DNDRulesActionHideBullet2: On a successful check, you have the Invisible condition. Make note of your check's total, which is the DC for a creature to find you with a Wisdom (Perception) check.
DNDRulesActionHideBullet3: The condition ends on you immediately after any of the following occurs: you make a sound louder than a whisper, an enemy finds you, you make an attack roll, or you cast a spell with a Verbal component.
DNDRulesActionUtilizeDescription: Use a nonmagical item or interact with an object separate from the free interaction
DNDRulesActionUtilizeBullet1: You normally interact with an object while doing something else, such as when you draw a sword as part of the Attack action. When an object requires an action for its use, you take the Utilize action.
DNDRulesActionUtilizeBullet2:
Time-Limited Object Interactions.
When time is short, such as in combat, interactions with objects are limited: one free interaction per turn. That interaction must occur during a creature's movement or action. Any additional interactions require the Utilize action.
DNDRulesActionUtilizeBullet3:
Breaking Objects.
As an action, you can automatically break or otherwise destroy a fragile, nonmagical object, such as a glass container or a piece of paper. If you try to damage something more resilient, the DM might use the rules on breaking objects in the rules glossary.
DNDRulesActionSearchBullet1: When you take the Search action, you make a Wisdom check to discern something that isn't obvious. The Search table suggests which skills are applicable when you take this action, depending on what you're trying to detect.
DNDRulesActionSearchBullet2:
SkillThing to Detect
InsightCreature's state of mind.
MedicineCreature's ailment or cause of death.
PerceptionConcealed creature or object.
SurvivalTracks or food.
DNDRulesActionStudyBullet1: When you take the Study action, you make an Intelligence check to study your memory, a book, a clue, or another source of knowledge and call to mind an important piece of information about it. </br></br> The Areas of Knowledge table suggests which skills are applicable to various areas of knowledge.
DNDRulesActionStudyBullet2:
SkillAreas
ArcanaSpells, magic items, eldritch symbols, magical traditions, planes of existence, and certain creatures (Aberrations, Constructs, Elementals, Fey, and Monstrosities)
HistoryHistoric events and people, ancient civilizations, wars, and certain creatures (Giants and Humanoids)
InvestigationTraps, ciphers, riddles, and gadgetry
NatureTerrain, flora, weather, and certain creatures (Beasts, Dragons, Oozes, and Plants)
ReligionDeities, religious hierarchies and rites, holy symbols, cults, and certain creatures (Celestials, Fiends, and Undead)
DNDRulesActionInfluenceBullet1: With the Influence action, you urge a creature to do something. Describe or roleplay how you're communicating with the creature. Are you trying to deceive, intimidate, amuse, or gently persuade? The DM then determines whether the creature feels willing, unwilling, or hesitant due to your interaction; this determination establishes whether an ability check is necessary, as explained below.
DNDRulesActionInfluenceBullet2:
Willing. If your urging aligns with the creature's desires, no ability check is necessary; the creature fulfills your request in a way it prefers.

Unwilling. If your urging is repugnant to the creature or counter to its alignment, no ability check is necessary; it doesn't comply.

Hesitant. If you urge the creature to do something that it is hesitant to do, you must make an ability check, which is affected by the creature's attitude: Indifferent, Friendly, or Hostile.

The Influence Checks table suggests which ability check to make based on how you're interacting with the creature. The GM chooses the check, which has a default DC equal to 15 or the creature's Int score, whichever is higher. On a successful check, the creature does as urged. On a failed check, you must wait 24 hours (or a duration set by the DM) before urging it in the same way again.
DNDRulesActionInfluenceBullet3:
Ability CheckInteraction
Charisma (Deception) Deceiving a creature that understands you.
Charisma (Intimidation)Intimidating a creature.
Charisma (Performance)Amusing a monster.
Charisma (Persuasion)Persuading a creature that understands you.
Wisdom (Animal Handling)Gently coaxing a Beast or Monstrosity.
DNDRulesActionReadyDescription: Choose a trigger and a response reaction
DNDRulesActionReadyBullet1: You take the Ready action to wait for a particular circumstance before you act. To do so, you take this action on your turn, which lets you act by taking a Reaction before the start of your next turn.
DNDRulesActionReadyBullet2: First, you decide what perceivable circumstance will trigger your Reaction. Then, you choose the action you will take in response to that trigger, or you choose to move up to your Speed in response to it.
DNDRulesActionReadyBullet3: When the trigger occurs, you can either take your Reaction right after the trigger finishes or ignore the trigger.
DNDRulesActionReadyBullet4: When you Ready a spell, you cast it as normal (expending any resources used to cast it) but hold its energy, which you release with your Reaction when the trigger occurs. To be readied, a spell must have a casting time of an action, and holding on to the spell's magic requires Concentration, which you can maintain up to the start of your next turn. If your Concentration is broken, the spell dissipates without taking effect.
DNDRulesActionUseClassFeatureDescription: Use a racial or class feature that uses an action
DNDRulesActionUseClassFeatureReference: See class page for more information.
DNDRulesActionImproviseSubtitle: Any action not on this list
DNDRulesActionImproviseDescription: Perform any action you can imagine
DNDRulesActionImproviseBullet1: Player characters and creatures can also do things not covered by other actions. Many class features and other abilities provide additional action options, and you can improvise other actions. When you describe an action not detailed elsewhere in the rules, the Dungeon Master tells you whether that action is possible and what kind of D20 Test you need to make, if any.
DNDRulesActionDisarmSubtitle: Knock item out of enemy's grasp
DNDRulesActionDisarmDescription: A creature can use a weapon attack to knock a weapon or another item from a target's grasp.
DNDRulesActionDisarmBullet2: The attacker makes an attack roll contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) check or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check.
DNDRulesActionDisarmBullet3: If the attacker wins the contest, the attack causes no damage or other ill effect, but the defender drops the item.
DNDRulesActionDisarmBullet4: The attacker has disadvantage on its attack roll if the target is holding the item with two or more hands.
DNDRulesActionDisarmBullet5: The target has advantage on its ability check if it is larger than the attacking creature, or disadvantage if it is smaller.
DNDRulesActionOverrunDescription: When a creature tries to move through a hostile creature's space, the mover can try to force its way through by overrunning the hostile creature.
DNDRulesActionOverrunBullet2: As an action, the mover makes a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the hostile creature's Strength (Athletics) check.
DNDRulesActionOverrunBullet3: The creature attempting the overrun has advantage on this check if it is larger than the hostile creature, or disadvantage if it is smaller.
DNDRulesActionOverrunBullet4: If the mover wins the contest, it can move through the hostile creature's space once this turn.
DNDRulesActionTumbleDescription: A creature can try to tumble through a hostile creature's space, ducking and weaving past the opponent.
DNDRulesActionTumbleBullet2: As an action, the tumbler makes a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by the hostile creature's Dexterity (Acrobatics) check.
DNDRulesActionTumbleBullet3: If the tumbler wins the contest, it can move through the hostile creature's space once this turn.
DNDRulesActionMarkDescription: This option makes it easier for melee combatants to harry each other with opportunity attacks.
DNDRulesActionMarkBullet2: When a creature makes a melee attack, it can also mark its target.
DNDRulesActionMarkBullet3: Until the end of the attacker's next turn, any opportunity attack it makes against the marked target has advantage.
DNDRulesActionMarkBullet4: The opportunity attack doesn't expend the attacker's reaction
DNDRulesActionMarkBullet5: The attacker can't make the attack if anything, such as the incapacitated condition or the shocking grasp spell, is preventing it from taking reactions.
DNDRulesActionMarkBullet6: The attacker is limited to one opportunity attack per turn.
DNDRulesActionClimbOntoABiggerCreatureDe: If one creature wants to jump onto another creature, it can do so by grappling. A suitably large opponent can be treated as terrain for the purpose of jumping onto its back or clinging to a limb.
DNDRulesActionClimbOntoABiggerCreatureBu: After making any ability checks necessary to get into position and onto the larger creature, the smaller creature uses its action to make a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by the target's Dexterity (Acrobatics) check.
If it wins the contest, the smaller creature successfully moves into the target creature's space.
The smaller creature moves with the target and has advantage on attack rolls against it.
DNDRulesConditionalActionDonOrDoffAShiel: A Shield can be donned or doffed as an action.
DNDRulesConditionalActionStabilizeACreat: Stop a dying creature from needing to make death saving throws
You can take the Help action to try to stabilize a creature with 0 Hit Points, which requires a successful DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check.
A Stable creature doesn't make Death Saving Throws even though it has 0 Hit Points, but it still has the Unconscious condition.
If the creature takes damage, it stops being Stable and starts making Death Saving Throws again.
A Stable creature that isn't healed regains 1 Hit Point after 1d4 hours.
DNDRulesConditionalActionEscapeAGrappleB: A Grappled creature can use its action to make a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check against the grapple's escape DC, ending the condition on itself on a success.
The condition also ends if the grappler has the Incapacitated condition or if the distance between the Grappled target and the grappler exceeds the grapple's range.
DNDRulesConditionalActionIdentifyASpellB: Sometimes a character wants to identify a spell that someone else is casting or that was already cast. To do so, a character can use their reaction to identify a spell as it's being cast, or they can use an action on their turn to identify a spell by its effect after it is cast.

If the character perceived the casting, the spell's effect, or both, the character can make an Intelligence (Arcana) check with the reaction or action. The DC equals 15 + the spell's level. If the spell is cast as a class spell and the character is a member of that class, the check is made with advantage. For example, if the spellcaster casts a spell as a cleric, another cleric has advantage on the check to identify the spell. Some spells aren't associated with any class when they're cast, such as when a monster uses its Innate Spellcasting trait.

This Intelligence (Arcana) check represents the fact that identifying a spell requires a quick mind and familiarity with the theory and practice of casting. This is true even for a character whose spellcasting ability is Wisdom or Charisma. Being able to cast spells doesn't by itself make you adept at deducing exactly what others are doing when they cast their spells.
DNDQuickReferenceCategoriesactionbonusDe: You can take a bonus action only when a special ability, spell, or feature states that you can do something as a bonus action.
DNDRulesBonusActionTwoWeaponFightingBull: Only usable if you take the Attack action and attack with a light weapon.
Perform a single attack with a different light weapon.
You don't add your ability modifier to the damage of the bonus attack, unless that modifier is negative.
DNDRulesBonusActionMagicDescription: Cast a spell with a casting time of 1 bonus action
DNDRulesBonusActionMagicBullet1: On a turn, you can expend only one spell slot to cast a spell. You can't, for example, cast a spell with a spell slot as your action and another one using your bonus action on the same turn.
DNDRulesBonusActionMagicBullet2: For further details, see the Cast a spell action.
DNDRulesBonusActionUseClassFeatureDescri: Use a racial or class feature that uses a bonus action
DNDRulesBonusActionUseClassFeatureRefere: See class page for more information.
DNDRulesBonusActionOverrunDescription: Shove a creature with a bonus action
DNDRulesBonusActionOverrunBullet1: As a bonus action, you can try to force a creature that is no more than one size larger than you to move out of your way.
DNDRulesBonusActionOverrunBullet2: You make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the creature’s Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (the creature chooses the check).
DNDRulesBonusActionOverrunBullet3: If you win the contest, you move the creature straight back a number of feet up to your speed. You can’t move through the space the creature vacated.
DNDRulesBonusActionOverrunBullet4: A creature that is immune to the prone condition is immune to this shove.
DNDRulesBonusActionTumbleDescription: Attempt to tumble through an enemy's space
DNDRulesBonusActionTumbleBullet1: As a bonus action, you can attempt to tumble through the space of an enemy.
DNDRulesBonusActionTumbleBullet2: Make a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by the creature’s Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. If you succeed, you can move through the creature’s space.
DNDQuickReferenceCategoriesreactionDescr: A reaction is an instant response to a trigger of some kind, which can occur on your turn or on someone else's.
DNDRulesReactionOpportunityAttackDescrip: You can rarely move heedlessly past your foes without putting yourself in danger
DNDRulesReactionOpportunityAttackBullet1: Trigger: enemy creature you can see leaves your reach using its action, its Bonus Action, its Reaction or one of its Speeds.
DNDRulesReactionOpportunityAttackBullet2: Make one melee attack with a weapon or an unarmed strike against the provoking creature.
DNDRulesReactionOpportunityAttackBullet3: The attack occurs right before the creature leaves your reach.
DNDRulesReactionReadiedActionDescription: Execute the reaction specified by your Ready action
DNDRulesReactionReadiedActionBullet1: Trigger and Reaction: specified by your Ready action.
DNDRulesReactionCastASpellDescription: Cast a spell with a casting time of 1 reaction
DNDRulesReactionCastASpellBullet2: For further details, see the Cast a spell action.
DNDRulesReactionIdentifyASpellDescriptio: Use your reaction to identify a spell as it's cast or right after it finishes
DNDRulesReactionIdentifyASpellBullet1: To identify a spell, you must be able to see or hear the spell being cast or perceive some other evidence of it with your senses.
DNDRulesReactionIdentifyASpellBullet2: You can try to identify a spell when a creature casts it or uses a magic item to cast it.  You must make an Intelligence (Arcana) check.
DNDRulesReactionIdentifyASpellBullet3: The DC equals 10 + the spell's level. If you succeed, you learn the spell's name, its school of magic, and what its effects are.
DNDQuickReferenceCategoriesconditionDesc: Conditions alter your capabilities in a variety of ways, and can arise as a result of a spell, a class feature, a monster's attack, or other effect.
DNDRulesConditionBlindedBullet1: You automatically fail any ability check that requires sight.
DNDRulesConditionBlindedBullet2: You have Disadvantage on attack rolls.
DNDRulesConditionBlindedBullet3: Attack rolls against you have Advantage.
DNDRulesConditionCharmedDescription: You are charmed by another creature
DNDRulesConditionCharmedBullet1: You can't attack the charmer or target them with damaging abilities or magical effects.
DNDRulesConditionCharmedBullet2: The charmer has Advantage on ability checks to interact with you socially.
DNDRulesConditionDeafenedBullet1: You automatically fail any ability check that requires hearing.
DNDRulesConditionExhaustionDescription: Exhaustion is measured in six levels
DNDRulesConditionExhaustionBullet2: This condition is cumulative. Each time you receive it, you gain 1 Exhaustion level. You die if your Exhaustion level is 6.
DNDRulesConditionExhaustionBullet3: Finishing a long rest reduces your exhaustion level by 1. When your Exhaustion level reaches 0, the condition ends.
DNDRulesConditionFrightenedBullet1: You have Disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls while the source of fear is within line of sight.
DNDRulesConditionFrightenedBullet2: You can't willingly move closer to the source of fear.
DNDRulesConditionGrappledBullet1: Your speed is 0 and can't increase.
DNDRulesConditionGrappledBullet2: You have Disadvantage on attack rolls against any target other than the grappler.
DNDRulesConditionGrappledBullet3: The grappler can drag or carry you when it moves, but every foot of movement costs 1 extra foot unless you are Tiny or 2 or more sizes smaller.
DNDRulesConditionIncapacitatedSubtitle: You can't take actions or reactions
DNDRulesConditionIncapacitatedDescriptio: You can't take actions or reactions
DNDRulesConditionIncapacitatedBullet3: You have Disadvantage on Initiative rolls.
DNDRulesConditionInvisibleDescription: You can't be seen without the aid of magic or a special sense
DNDRulesConditionInvisibleBullet1: You have Advantage on Initiative rolls and attack rolls unless your target can somehow see you.
DNDRulesConditionInvisibleBullet2: Attack rolls against you have Disadvantage, unless your attacker can somehow see you
DNDRulesConditionInvisibleBullet3: You aren't affected by any effect that requires its target to be seen unless the effect's creator can somehow see you. Any equipment you are wearing or carrying is also concealed.
DNDRulesConditionParalyzedBullet2: Your speed is 0 and can't increase.
DNDRulesConditionParalyzedBullet3: Attack rolls against you have Advantage and any attack that hits you is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of you.
DNDRulesConditionParalyzedBullet4: You automatically fail Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
DNDRulesConditionPetrifiedDescription: You are transformed, along with any nonmagical objects you are wearing or carrying, into a solid inanimate substance (usually stone)
DNDRulesConditionPetrifiedBullet1: Your weight increases by a factor of ten, and you cease aging.
DNDRulesConditionPetrifiedBullet3: Your speed is 0 and can't increase.
DNDRulesConditionPetrifiedBullet4: Attack rolls against you have Advantage.
DNDRulesConditionPetrifiedBullet5: You automatically fail Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
DNDRulesConditionPetrifiedBullet6: You have resistance to all damage.
DNDRulesConditionPetrifiedBullet7: You have Immunity to the Poisoned condition.
DNDRulesConditionPoisonedBullet1: You have Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.
DNDRulesConditionProneBullet1: Your only movement option is to crawl, unless you stand up. If your speed is 0, you can't stand up.
DNDRulesConditionProneBullet2: You have Disadvantage on attack rolls.
DNDRulesConditionProneBullet3: Attack rolls against you have Advantage if the attacker is within 5 feet of you, otherwise the attack roll has Disadvantage.
DNDRulesConditionRestrainedBullet1: Your speed is 0 and can't increase.
DNDRulesConditionRestrainedBullet2: You have Disadvantage on attack rolls.
DNDRulesConditionRestrainedBullet3: Attack rolls against you have Advantage.
DNDRulesConditionRestrainedBullet4: You have Disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws.
DNDRulesConditionStunnedBullet2: Attack rolls against you have Advantage.
DNDRulesConditionStunnedBullet3: You automatically fail Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
DNDRulesConditionUnconsciousBullet1: You have the Incapacitated and Prone conditions and you drop whatever you're holding.
DNDRulesConditionUnconsciousBullet2: Your speed is 0 and can't increase.
DNDRulesConditionUnconsciousBullet3: Attack rolls against you have Advantage.
DNDRulesConditionUnconsciousBullet4: Any attack that hits you is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of you.
DNDRulesConditionUnconsciousBullet5: You automatically fail Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
DNDRulesConditionDyingDescription: You have been dropped to zero hit points and are dying
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet1: If you are reduced to 0 hit points by damage that fails to kill you, you fall unconscious and are dying.
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet2: If you receive any healing you immediately regain consciousness and are no longer dying.
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet3: When you start your turn with 0 hit points, you must make a Death Saving Throw without modifiers.
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet4: 10 or higher is a success, 9 or lower is a failure.
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet5: On your third success, you become stable.
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet6: On your third failure, you die.
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet7: Rolling a 1 counts as two failures.
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet8: Rolling a 20 immediately causes you to regain 1 hit point.
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet9: If you take damage while dying, you suffer a failure. If it's from a critical hit, you suffer 2 failures.
DNDRulesConditionDyingBullet10: You can be stabilized by an ally taking the Help (Stabilize) action and succeeding on a DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check. Once stable, you are at 0 HP, still unconscious, but no longer dying. You regain 1 hit point after 1d4 hours if not healed.
DNDQuickReferenceCategoriesenvironmentSu: Effects that obscure vision can prove a significant hindrance to most adventuring tasks.
DNDRulesEnvironmentObscuranceLightlyObsc: Dim light, patchy fog, moderate foliage.
Creatures have Disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.
DNDRulesEnvironmentObscuranceHeavilyObsc: Creatures have the Blinded condition, when trying to see something.
DNDQuickReferenceCategoriesenvironmentSu: The presence or absence of light in an environment creates three categories of illumination.
DNDRulesEnvironmentLightBrightLightDescr: Bright light lets most creatures see normally
DNDRulesEnvironmentLightBrightLightBulle: Gloomy days still provide bright light, as do torches, lanterns, fires, and other sources of illumination within a specific radius.
DNDRulesEnvironmentLightDimLightBullet2: An area of dim light is usually a boundary between a source of bright light, such as a torch, and surrounding darkness.
DNDRulesEnvironmentLightDimLightBullet3: The soft light of twilight and dawn also counts as dim light. A particularly brilliant full moon might bathe the land in dim light.
DNDRulesEnvironmentLightDarknessDescript: Darkness creates a heavily obscured area
DNDRulesEnvironmentLightDarknessBullet2: Characters face darkness outdoors at night (even most moonlit nights), within the confines of an unlit dungeon or a subterranean vault, or in an area of magical darkness.
DNDQuickReferenceCategoriesenvironmentSu: Some creatures have extraordinary senses that allow them to perceive their environment.
DNDRulesEnvironmentVisionBlindsightDescr: You can see within a specified range without relying on physical sight.
DNDRulesEnvironmentVisionBlindsightBulle: You can see anything that isn't behind Total Cover even if you have the Blinded condition or are in Darkness.
You can see something that has the Invisible condition.
Creatures without eyes, such as oozes, and creatures with echolocation or heightened senses, such as bats and true dragons, have this sense.
DNDRulesEnvironmentVisionDarkvisionDescr: A creature with Darkvision can see better in the dark or low light conditions, within a certain radius
DNDRulesEnvironmentVisionDarkvisionBulle: Within a specified range, a creature with darkvision can see in Dim Light as if it were Bright Light and in Darkness as if it were Dim Light.
However, the creature can’t discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.
Many creatures in the worlds of D&D, especially those that dwell underground, have darkvision.
DNDRulesEnvironmentVisionTremorsenseDesc: pinpoint location of creatures in contact with the same surfaces you are
DNDRulesEnvironmentVisionTremorsenseBull: Within a specified range, a creature with Tremorsense can pinpoint the location of creatures and moving objects, provided that the creature with Tremorsense and anything it is detecting are both in contact with the same surface or liquid.
Tremorsense can't detect creatures in the air, and it doesn't count as a form of sight.
DNDRulesEnvironmentVisionTruesightDescri: Your vision is enhanced within a specified range, it pierces the following
DNDRulesEnvironmentVisionTruesightBullet: You can see in normal and magical Darkness.
You can see creatures and objects that have the Invisible condition.
Visual illusions appear transparent to you, and you automatically succeed on saving throws against them.
You discern the true form of any creature or object you see that has been transformed by magic.
You see into the Ethereal Plane.
DNDQuickReferenceCategoriesenvironmentSu: Obstacles can provide cover during combat, making a target more difficult to harm.
DNDRulesEnvironmentCoverHalfCoverDescrip: A target has half cover if an obstacle blocks at least half of its body
DNDRulesEnvironmentCoverHalfCoverBullet1: The obstacle might be a low wall, a large piece of furniture, a narrow tree trunk, or a creature, whether that creature is an enemy or a friend.
DNDRulesEnvironmentCoverHalfCoverBullet2: A target with half cover has a +2 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws.
DNDRulesEnvironmentCoverHalfCoverBullet3: If a target is behind multiple sources of cover, only the most protective degree of cover applies
DNDRulesEnvironmentCoverThreeQuartersCov: A target has three-quarters cover if about three-quarters of it is covered by an obstacle
The obstacle might be a portcullis, an arrow slit, or a thick tree trunk.
A target with three-quarters cover has a +5 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws.
If a target is behind multiple sources of cover, only the most protective degree of cover applies
DNDRulesEnvironmentCoverFullCoverDescrip: A target has total cover if it is completely concealed by an obstacle
DNDRulesEnvironmentCoverFullCoverBullet1: A target with total cover can’t be targeted directly by an attack or a spell, although some spells can reach such a target by including it in an area of effect.
DNDRulesEnvironmentCoverFullCoverBullet2: If a target is behind multiple sources of cover, only the most protective degree of cover applies
